passages.name: forget
passages.text:
Mr. Hoth’s eyes, brown and unassuming, seem to pity as you stand, but you don’t know why. You leave with an arm full of glowing references, and the nagging feeling that something has been left behind.

On the way home, you pass by a bookshop. The new Rebecca Butler — Rebecca Butler and the Marauding Monster — will be out in a few months. You nip inside and make sure you pre-order it, already getting ready to share into another magical adventure.<<remember $forgetend to true>>

It’s silly to think about, but still, wouldn’t it be cool if magic were real?

[[The End|end credits]]

passages.name: your dad
passages.text:
A voicemail from your dad is very rarely something to look forward to. It’s all subtle barbs and hints to come back home and join the family business. He knows the money your grandma left you won’t last much longer.

But it’ll take more than a guilt trip to make you give up.

[[Back to your bag.|your bag]]
[[Back to the waiting room.|waiting room]]

passages.name: wh mongoose defeat
passages.text:
The Banishment Sigil is simple, taking advantage of the universe’s already burning desire to fly away from itself. 

You feel a slight tinge of magic as you trace the symbol in the air. It feels like ants running up your spine.

The sigil summons something like a gust of wind, that startles the mongoose away, sending it out into the shadows. You grab the post-it notes, dusted with fur, and [[head back.|wh end test]]<<set $post to true>>

passages.name: books
passages.text:
You find the pile of books you need huddled in a pile in the shadows, as if they’d been running from something. They don’t move as you approach though, and flip through them, skimming white words off pitch black pages.

They don’t quite make sense to you, but maybe eventually they will.

You cross the books off your list.

<<if $map>>[[Go straight to the pens.|pens]]<<endif>>
[[Towards a distant glow.|stars]]
[[Towards the rustle of wings.|paper birds]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: Home CSS
nets
passages.text:
In a pile atop a box, there’s a stack of glittering silver nets. They’re soft to the touch, metallic, but flow like water over your fingers. Most of them have been ripped by something with tiny persistent teeth.

<<if visited("capture") is false>>[[A flicker above you.|capture]]<<endif>>
[[Towards the growls.|chimera]] 
[[Towards the smell of disrepair.|rusted sigils]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: human right
passages.text: You turn away before they can say anything else, but you have to wonder. Are they right?\n\n[[Back to the cafe.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: rusted sigils
passages.text:
In an unmarked box, there are thousands of sigils like yours. Only while yours is golden and giving, these are rusted and decayed. You try to take one and it crumbles in your grasp. They were never meant to last.

[[Towards the cauldron cairn.|wh left]] 
[[Towards what feels like a trap.|nets]] 
[[Towards the snores.|sleeping heads]]
[[Towards the growing piles.|forest]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

links.text: Towards what feels like a trap.

passages.name: pens
passages.text:
Near the river, a group of glimmering reptiles laze near the flowing current. You harvest the tortoiseshell pens, still attached to their tortoises. 

By now, you’d think they’d have upgraded to ballpoint, but then again you don’t want to think about what those are harvested from.

You cross pens off your list.

<<if $map>>[[Go straight to the books.|books]]<<endif>>
[[Back to the river.|river of ink]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: bell
passages.text:
The wood of boxes clears, and before you there is a bell. It’s small and bronze and would look more at home on the desk of a hotel concierge, instead of perched on a stack of taped closed books.

Your journey here has proven only one thing to you.

You definitely need assistance.

[[Ring the bell.|ring bell]]

passages.name: wh portal
passages.text: You’ve gotten used to the feeling of the portals by now, the way they cling to your skin as you enter, the way the air gets heavy and scented. You can’t say it makes you feel good, just being in the Otherworld makes you feel like shit afterwards, but it does make you feel alive.\n\nEven when the exotic magical locations look more like [[a hoarder’s house|wh center]] than anything you’d find in a Rebecca Butler book.

passages.name: StoryTitle
passages.text: Arcane Intern (Unpaid)

passages.name: excited
passages.text:
But there doesn’t seem to be anything magical about your cubicle. In fact, the cheap plastic desk, burdened down by reams of paper looks even more mundane than anything you’ve seen before. There’s an old computer there, so old that you wouldn’t be surprised if magic was the only thing that kept it running. 

Overall, it looks like a shit workstation, and not a magical place. Not even a magical intern place.

The Hiring Manager just smiles as he leaves you there. [[Someone should come by soon|cubicle]] to explain what they want you to do with these.

passages.name: wh try 2
passages.text:
Mind and muscle conspire together to force reality to buckle ever so slightly. The sigil is carved in the air and then launches itself at the mongoose.

The creature twists and writhes under every stroke, but eventually the sigil sinks into it and it falls calm.
Nose twitching, it grabs a pack of post-it notes and trots right up to you. [[You walk back down the hallway|wh end test]], petting its soft fur as it coils around your neck. <<set $mongoose to true>><<set $post to true>>

links.text: You walk back down the hallway

passages.name: no copy sigil
passages.text: After what you’ve seen the copier do, you don’t want to take the risk. You finish the book, and add it back to the pile.\n\n[[Back to work|cr 2]]

passages.name: smile end
passages.text:
She makes it sound like such a good idea. Drunk off power and wine, you both stumble to the computer, conspiracy thick in the air.

It might not change much. Hell, it might not change anything, but a simple sketch and click and the sigil is up.

Taylor keeps making plans, about getting everyone she knows this tattoo, but you can only stare at the page.

The world is full of magic. Isn’t it high time everyone knew it too?<<remember $magicend to true>>

[[The End|end credits]]

passages.name: return
passages.text:
The air is lighter. A weight you didn’t know had pressed into your lungs is gone. Just being back in the real world makes you feel more solid, more stable.

And yet, something has still been torn from you.

Still, you aren’t bleeding, no matter the lack you feel. You finish your job. You deliver all the coffees. Nigel doesn’t smile or thank you at all when you arrive with a perfectly warm Draconian latte.

You didn’t expect him to, but it still feels like an extra tear within you.

[[You trudge back to your desk.|desk coffee]]

links.text: You trudge back to your desk.

passages.name: ring bell
passages.text:
You drop your hand onto the tiny bronze bell and it rings, once. Short and clear and sounding exactly like a normal bell.
You look around.

Nothing seems to have happened.

You try to ring it again, but it makes no sound even as you pound your hand into it. <<set $bell to true>>

[[Go back to the entryway.|wh end test]]
[[Go back to the crossroad with the sigils.|rusted sigils]]

links.text: Go back to the crossroad with the sigils.

passages.name: early
passages.text:
It’s a good thing you left early, because this building was much harder to find than you imagined. It didn’t come up on any Map search, and they didn’t even have a website. You had to look for the building at the corner, and then walk down the street in order to even find it at all.

But then again, publishing houses aren’t stores, so maybe Praecantatio is worried about people storming the place for unreleased books. It happened with the last Rebecca Butler book, so maybe they got worried.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: warehouse
passages.text:
“Some Otherworld snakes broke into our storage room here and ate most of our supplies, as well as a few copies of books we were supposed to send out to reviewers. I’d send someone else to do it, but we need those things now and the Janitor is busy trying to beat back those snakes. So I’m sending you. Do try to get it done quickly.”

She doesn’t seem to have much faith in you.

“Go down there and get us new pens, post-it notes and copies of those books. Try not to get lost.”

[[Head towards the warehouse.|wh find]]

passages.name: hag intern
passages.text:
She cackles. One of her warts has a glittering piercing through it. “It’s your sigil,” she says, gesturing at the sigil you were given when you started. “Anyone wearing one never stays forever.”

You want to ask more, but the dragon rumbles a name and she goes to get her coffee. 

[[Back to the cafe.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: basement
passages.text:
<<if visited("olivia coffee") AND visited("recept manage")>>
The door opens. A set of stairs leads down into a swirling pit. Oddly enough, it does smell like coffee.

[[Descend.|Descend]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]
<<else>>
You don’t have all the orders you need yet. Showing up without the coffee is hardly what will impress on your first day.

[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]<<endif>>

passages.name: waiting room
passages.text:
<<if $minutes gte 2>>It’s <<print $minutes>> minutes until your interview. Good thing you were [[early][$minutes -=1]].<<else>><<goto "Ready">><<endif>>

There’s a large plaque on the wall reading “[[Praecantatio Publishers][$minutes -=1]]” along with some [[weird symbols][$minutes -=1]]. The rest of the waiting room looks like it was lifted from a brochure, plastic plants and all.

The [[receptionist][$minutes -=1]] already signed you in. She now sits behind an ornate wooden desk, flipping through a ridiculously large book. Behind her, a closed door reads HR. 

Next to your seat, there’s a basket full of [[magazines][$minutes -=1]], and [[your bag][$minutes -=1]].

passages.name: recept manage
passages.text:
“He’s busy at the moment, but I know his order. A Turkish Coffee. They’ll be able to give it to you to go.”

[[Ask her for her coffee order.|recept coffee]]
[[Ask about the different floors.|recept floors]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her for her coffee order.

passages.name: magic
passages.text:
You remember being eleven, and burying yourself in fantasy books. It was so much better than the real world, even at that age.

With the blind confidence only a child could have, you told your father you were going away to magic school. “Magic isn’t real,” he’d said, something he’d come to repeat over and over again.

So the question remains, Do you believe in magic?

[[Yes.|yes magic]]
[[No.|no magic]]

passages.name: human screw
passages.text: Seems like magicians still understand rude gestures, because they splutter and huff. You turn before they recover and say anything else.\n\n[[Back to the cafe.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: recept coffee
passages.text:
“Well aren’t you sweet. The last intern didn’t even bother asking me, went straight to Mr. Hoth.” 

She taps her fingers idly against the same giant book she had before. The symbols look familiar and foreign all at once.

“I’ll have a Double Shot Expresso.”

[[Don’t you mean Espresso?|expresso]]
[[Ask about the different floors.|recept floors]]
[[Ask her what she’s smiling about.|recept smile]]
[[Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.|recept manage]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her what she’s smiling about.
Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.

passages.name: sleeping heads
passages.text:
Well this is unnerving. 

There are heads propped up in jars among the boxes. At first you think them dead, until one of them snores and rolls in its jar. It seems they’re only sleeping.

[[Towards the rustle of wings.|paper birds]]
[[Towards a distant glow.|stars]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: theory
passages.text:
You read, soaking in every line, ever swoop of the pen. Soon, one day, you will cast these. You will etch them into every place that surrounds you and bring the magic into your world by force.

This is so much better than any Rebecca Butler book. Those books may have offered you an escape into a world of magic, but this gives you the real thing.

You read far into the morning, and only [[fall asleep|ch4]] when your eyes literally can’t stay open any longer.

passages.name: human problem
passages.text:
You lift your chin, defiant. They seem utterly unimpressed.

“Your kind isn’t wanted here, so just run on back out the portal.” 

You can’t hide the confusion on your face — aren’t they human too — and one of them scoffs. “No magic, no entry. Just cause you got yourself a viewing sigil doesn’t mean you belong.”

Oh. They think you’re a mundane, like the regular people in the Rebecca Butler series.

[[Screw them. You know you belong here.|human screw]]
[[Maybe they’re right? You don’t know anything about magic.|human right]]

links.text: Screw them. You know you belong here.
Maybe they’re right? You don’t know anything about magic.

passages.name: truth
passages.text:
You haltingly explain about magic, about the Otherworld that lies tangent to ours, leaking but never mixing. Like oil and water.

She grapples to understand, even as her own mind works against her. She doesn’t have a sigil on her like you do, so your spell seems to only go so far.

[[Give her a sigil somehow.|t sigil]]
[[Try to undo your spell.|undo]]

passages.name: wish
passages.text:
“Thanks. You’re sweet.” A sigh, a thump on wood. “But I’ll get it done, eventually, don’t you worry.”

[[Move on.|delivery]]
<<if $mongoose>>[[Offer up the mongoose.|j mongoose]]<<endif>>

passages.name: Ready
passages.text:
It’s time for your interview.

The receptionist doesn’t even look up from her giant book. She just calls your name and nods back.

The door to the office behind her is [[open now.|interview]]

passages.name: references
passages.text:
“We will, of course provide you with glowing references once your time with us is complete. All of our previous interns have gone on to have exemplary careers.”

At this point a reference letter sounds like winning the lottery. With your interview track record, you don’t really have the luxury of turning this down.

[[Take the Job.|employ]]

passages.name: wh mongoose capture
passages.text:
You’ve never cast before, but you’ve pieced together how from your week here. Some part determination, some part focus, most parts knowledge. And without a sigil taught to you, there had been nothing to test with.

But now the knowledge burns in your mind, and you can feel it spark in your fingers.

You trace the capture sigil in the air.

Nothing happens.

[[Try again.|wh try]]
<<if $banish>>[[Cast the simpler Banishment Sigil.|wh mongoose defeat]]<<endif>>

passages.name: ofc sir
passages.text:
He smiles, impressed by your fake-as-hell manners.

“Draconian Latte with Hazelnut.”

They definitely don’t serve that at Starbucks.

[[Ask where you can get a ‘Draconian Latte’.|otherworld nigel]]

links.text: Ask where you can get a ‘Draconian Latte’.

passages.name: sbucks
passages.text:
He laughs, the way a least favorite uncle laughs at his own terrible jokes.

“You’ll hardly be going to Starbucks. There’s an Otherworld coffee shop we frequent in the basement. You’ll recognize the markings.”

[[Otherworld?|otherworld nigel]]
[[Okay, got it.|coffee start]]

passages.name: last give
passages.text:
You knew this couldn’t last forever. 

Still, you move a bit reluctantly, urged on by the weight behind his voice.

<<if $tattoo>>No matter what you might really want, [[you drop it in his hand.|knowing]]<<else>>No matter what you might really want, [[you drop it in his hand.|forget]]<<endif>>

links.text: you drop it in his hand.
you drop it in his hand.

passages.name: humans
passages.text:
Among the gremlins and hags, manticores and dragons, humans stand out like a sore thumb. These particular humans stand out more than most thanks to the way they glare at you. 

[[Ask them what their problem is.|human problem]]
[[Just ignore them.|cafe hoard]]

links.text: Ask them what their problem is.

passages.name: on the other side
passages.text:
The portal drops you off directly in front of an Otherworld coffee shop called ‘Caffeine Hoard’. Even though everything else looks the same, you can tell you aren’t in your world from two main clues:

Firstly, the air feels different here, as if it’s spiced with clove and hard to breathe.

The second is that a gigantic dragon's tail curves from out the back of the store, and you’re sure you didn’t see any of those walking around yesterday.

[[Walk inside.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: wh end
passages.text:
With everything crossed off your list, you return to the portal, nodding a goodbye to the skull.

<<if $mongoose>>Your new mongoose sits heavy across your collar, but warm, in the same way a favorite toy or blanket might be.<<endif>>

Reluctantly, even though you feel the air here poison your very being, [[you step back into your own world.|own world]]

links.text: you step back into your own world.

passages.name: computer
passages.text:
You manage to boot up the computer, even though it takes forever and Oh god, it’s running Windows 95.

Maybe it was cursed? That has to be the reason. No one would willingly use Windows 95, would they?

[[Back to your desk.|cubicle]]

passages.name: wh find
passages.text:
The entrance to the warehouse is three floors up, and next to what is labeled the storage room but currently sounds like it holds a wrestling ring. Cheering and everything.

[[Knock on the storage room door.|sr door]]
[[Enter the warehouse.|wh portal]]

links.text: Knock on the storage room door.

passages.name: home
passages.text:
Today had felt particularly trying, exhausting in a way even the toxic Otherworld can't achieve. You trudge back home, ignoring the flickers of magic you keep catching out of the corner of your eye.

But home, as always, feels pretty great. Taylor is already there before you touching up her newest piece.

“Rough day at work?”

You think of the hell that is the copy room and feel something rise in you, bitter and burning.

[[Stay up and talk to Taylor.|Taylor]]
[[Just head to bed.|bed]]

links.text: Stay up and talk to Taylor.

passages.name: goto
Rebecca Butler
passages.text:
It’s no understatement to say that the Rebecca Butler books changed your life. They swept in when you were just a kid and carried you away into a world of magic, mystery and adventure that you feel you never really left.

You want to bring that magic to other people too. That’s why you’re here waiting for this interview.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: olivia coffee
passages.text:
Ms. Singh ushers you in with a terse word as she brandishes a red pen over paper. The red ink struggles to place itself onto the pages.

“A large Masala Chai. Just leave it on the desk when you get back.”

She continues her struggle to correct the text in front of her. Despite your curiosity at what it might have said, you leave the office. That ink didn’t look like it would stay put on the page for long.

[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

passages.name: Colors
passages.text:
“Interesting… Where do you see yourself 500 years from now?”

[[Dead.|Dead]]
[[Don’t you mean 5 years?|Dead]]
[[Talk about your dream of publishing the next Rebecca Butler series. It must have been a mistake.|Dead]]

links.text: Talk about your dream of publishing the next Rebecca Butler series. It must have been a mistake.

passages.name: beckons
passages.text:
The open door belongs to Nigel Scott and he waves you into the office. It looks like any other office, except for the abomination of a computer that seems to have been transported here from the 90s.

Nigel himself looks... normal. Bald head, a smooth voice, eyes that don’t look like black holes. Like any other marketing director. After the Hiring Manager, you expected something a bit more bizarre.

But then he makes up for his lack of strangeness with rudeness.

“Can’t imagine what they were thinking taking on an outsider, but you’re what we’ve got now so we might as well make the best of it.”

“Later today, I want you putting in the old financial data on your desk into that computer thing Accounting keeps raving about. But for now, we’ll give you an easy task, something even you can handle.”

“Go get the office some coffee.”

[[Of course, sir. What would you like?|ofc sir]]
[[The nearest Starbucks is a little far from here, but okay.|sbucks]]

links.text: Of course, sir. What would you like?
The nearest Starbucks is a little far from here, but okay.

passages.name: skull map
passages.text:
How it rolled its eyes at you, you don’t know, but it sure as hell did.

“Fine. Here.” 

You feel a glow in the back of your mind. All the locations will be much easier to find now.<<set $map to true>>

<<if $skullname AND visited("skull help") is 0>>[[Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.|skull help]]<<endif>>
[[Ask about the warehouse.|skull warehouse]]
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]

links.text: Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.

passages.name: desk coffee
passages.text:
You toy with your golden amulet, your key into that Otherworld, all through work, as you copy numbers from paper onto an ancient spreadsheet. If it weren’t for the tinge of sulfur, of dragon’s breath, still clinging to you, you’d still think it was all a dream.

Even Taylor’s excellent quesadilla dinner couldn’t perk you up. Not when she is blind to this world, and you still feel so separate from it.

Falling asleep is hard, but you manage, feeling [[the warm sigil under your fingers.|ch3]]

links.text: the warm sigil under your fingers.

passages.name: jumper
passages.text:
If this isn't your first time playing Arcane Intern (Unpaid), then you can navigate your to-do list here. <>

Intern To-Do List

<>
    <>
  1. [[Get Coffee|ch2]]
    2. <> <>
  2. [[Restock Storage Room|ch3]]
    3. <> <>
  3. [[Making Copies|ch4]]
    4. <>
[[Back to Front Page|Start]]

passages.name: knowing
passages.text:
It’s as if the world should have ended, and it didn’t. The sigil drops, and the world stays just as it is. Mr. Hoth’s eyes are still depthless pits, as he smiles and hands you some glowing reference letters.

You leave as soon as you can, before they notice the books you’ve stuffed in your bag. Though you doubt they ever will. 
Still, you can’t run from the heavy weight of what you’ve done, of what you’ve taken from them. Not just the books, but the secrets.

<<if $taylor>>You only feel like they won’t just show up and try to take it all away once you get home and [[close the door.|home taylor]]<<else>>You only feel like they won’t just show up and try to take it all away once you get home and [[close the door.|home door]]<<endif>>

passages.name: weird symbols
passages.text:
Sinuous curves and slashing lines form a border around the plaque on the wall. They waver slightly, and you look away.

It’s not like they’re important, and that plant in the corner looks much more interesting.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: janitor coffee
passages.text:
The door is locked. The lights seem to flicker inside as a friendly voice says, “Oh, the new intern. I figured they’d send you on a coffee run soon. Pumpkin Spice Latte for me, if you don’t mind.”

The door never opens. The lights never stop.

[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

passages.name: StorySettings
passages.text:
jquery:off
hash:off
bookmark:off
modernizr:off
undo:off
obfuscate:off
exitprompt:off
blankcss:on

passages.name: paper birds
passages.text:
You come across a pile of cages, full to the brim with paper birds. The area is full of the fluttering of pulpy wings and the bright shine of sigils across beaks.

[[Towards the perfume of paper.|books]]
[[Towards the smell of disrepair.|rusted sigils]]
[[Towards a distant glow.|stars]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: put it on
passages.text:
Keycards seem more efficient, but whatever. You put on the chain, feeling the metal symbol hot against your skin.

Actually, now that you’re wearing it, you can see it more clearly. It looks like an eye, stylized and twisted, but an eye nonetheless. 

You look back up to ask the Hiring Manager what it means and [[you startle]].

passages.name: copy room
passages.text:
The copy room is a depressing little shack curled up between the break room and the bathroom.

A [[modified Xerox machine|c copy]], decades old and littered with sigils takes up most of the room. Beside it, [[a stack of old books|c examine]] rises all the way up to the ceiling.

<<if visited("c copy 2") AND visited("c examine")>>[[Take a break.|breakroom]]<<endif>>

passages.name: dont tell
passages.text: You keep it to yourself. It’s too crazy, too far fetched. She might have dragons tattooed up her arm, but the idea of real ones maybe existing just seems too far-fetched.\n\nStill, once you figure this out it might be nice to tell her. [[Once you actually know what the hell is going on.|ch2]]

links.text: Once you actually know what the hell is going on.

passages.name: wh try
passages.text:
You can do this.

You are more than just an intern, more than just a Temp. You can feel the magic in your breath. Your eyes have been opened, you know you can do this.

You wrangle your thoughts into the shape of the thing, breathe it, feel it. If you could, your veins would be twisted to trace its pattern, your hair curled to follow its lines.

[[You trace the sigil again.|wh try 2]]

passages.name: undo
passages.text:
It isn’t easy, to look her in the eye and watch them widen as you draw the sigil in the air. It isn’t simple as you push you power onto her and watch knowledge drain out of her like water through her hands.

She blinks, and smiles so kindly it twists at you. “Still want some tea?”

You shake your head and [[go to bed|last day]]. It’s probably better this way.

passages.name: wh mongoose
passages.text:
You finally make it to something new, an pile of unopened post-it notes. But you can’t just take them. They are guarded by a ferocious beast.

Well, a tiny ferocious beast. A mongoose huddles over the notes, a snarling, sinuous line of fur and fang. You try to shoo it away, but it doesn’t budge.

<<if $find>>[[Cast the Banishment Sigil|wh mongoose defeat]]<<endif>>
<<if $capture>>[[Cast the Capture Sigil|wh mongoose capture]]<<endif>>
[[Get away from it.|wh center]]

passages.name: Get Coffee
passages.text:
That weekend, you reread all of the Rebecca Butler books in order to try and grapple with the fact that magic is real.
 
It’s real and it’s yours now.

What you thought would be just another unpaid internship has given you access to a whole new world. It is a world because you’ve seen it. Buildings marked, books you never saw in bookstores. Things that were hidden from your eyes before now seem to almost glow, as if their very existence has been highlighted.

This is what your new job is going to be about. Magic. [[And you’ve never been more excited.|excited]]

links.text: And you’ve never been more excited.

passages.name: hipster hag
passages.text:
Her nose is dotted with some of the largest warts you've ever seen, but at the same time her face would look incomplete without them. 

"Being a Temp doesn't give you an excuse to stare," she smirks that revealing her pointed teeth.

[[Ask how she knew you were an intern.|hag intern]]
[[Mutter an apology and go.|hag excuse]]

links.text: Ask how she knew you were an intern.

passages.name: both
passages.text: She doesn’t have a sigil yet. You pull out the page and show her the design, holding on frantically to her understanding. Her resulting grin would send a shiver down the devil’s spine, but it only sends a thrill down yours. “Yes. Of course I want it. Let’s do it.” She does yours first. Just in case. You can feel the coils of power as she draws, as you work in tandem. Even now, half blind, she tugs at the fabric of reality. She will be glorious at this, you can tell. Yours locks in with a snap of power, but hers, placed snugly in a blank patch of skin, seals shut with a clatter. You both sit breathless for a moment, before smiling. In the dead of night, the world seems bright with possibility. You lend her one of the books you’ve already finished, and reluctantly, buzzing with energy and exhaustion, [[go to sleep|last day]].<><>

passages.name: sr start
passages.text:
By the end of the first week, you know you’re being taken for granted.

Never mind that you’re the only person who actually knows what Excel is, let alone Twitter.

Never mind that the dragon down at Caffeine Hoard — calls himself George — has grown fond of you and gives you free cookies with your order now, burnt crisp all around the edges.

Never mind that you hustle and get all the work done faster than anyone else could. Your coworkers still look at you like an outsider, and the golden sigil only gets you scorn from most of the denizens of the other world.

Today, like most days, the reward for your hard work is [[more grunt work|grunt]]. Like you’re more minion than magic.

passages.name: cr 2
passages.text: A [[modified Xerox machine|c copy 3]], decades old and littered with sigils takes up most of the room. <<if visited("examine 2")>>Beside it, a stack of old books rises all the way up to the ceiling.<<else>>Beside it, [[a stack of old books|examine 2]] rises all the way up to the ceiling.<<endif>>\n\n<<if visited("c copy 3") gte 2>>[[Call it a day.|home]]<<endif>>

passages.name: not pay
passages.text:
You step aside to wait for your order.

A few minutes later, the dragon rumbles a name you vaguely recognize as yours and you pickup the tray of colorfully steaming beverages.

They’ll get cold if you loiter, so you head back out, away from the ‘Caffeine Hoard’ and all its denizens.

Despite the experience, you can’t help but feel lonely [[once you return|return]].

passages.name: skull list 2
passages.text:
“Great! Don’t forget. River of ink. Paper birds or Stars. Mongoose. You’ll be out of here in no time.”

<<if $skullname AND visited("skull help") is 0>>[[Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.|skull help]]<<endif>>
[[Ask about the warehouse.|skull warehouse]]
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]

links.text: Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.

passages.name: door help
passages.text:
“Awful kind of you.” Grunt. Splash. “But I’ll be fine.” Whinny. Guitar Riff.

Pause.

“Though if you’re heading down into the warehouse, ask my cousin to see if he’s got anything that could help. Just call his name at the help desk and he’ll show.”

He gives you the name then. It twists around your tongue as you repeat it, making your mouth feel salty and slick.

[[Head to the warehouse.|wh portal]] <<set $skullname to true>>

passages.name: wh end test
passages.text: <<if (visited("pens") AND (visited("books")) AND $post)>><<goto "wh end">><<else>><<goto "wh center">><<endif>>

passages.name: cafe hoard
passages.text:
[[A crimson dragon|dragon]] sits upon a hoard of coffee beans, filling the store with the nutty scent of roasting beans. The queue snakes through the store, all leading towards him.

In the corner, [[a hag wearing wide brim glasses|hipster hag]] sips from a small steaming cauldron. She keeps shooting looks at you.

Meanwhile, a group of [[normal looking people|humans]] huddled over a book near the entrance keeps shooting you dirty looks.

You could go up to one of them, or you could just get in line and [[get this over with|queue]].

links.text: a hag wearing wide brim glasses

passages.name: Dead
passages.text:
“Ah, never gotten that answer before!” 

You highly doubt that.

“How good are you at keeping secrets?”

[[No good.|Secrets]]
[[Pretty good.|Secrets]]
[[I won’t do anything illegal.|Secrets]]

passages.name: queue
passages.text: You get in line behind what looks like a swamp creature, and a werewolf. The cashier, a pale young girl takes orders quickly and efficiently.\n\nWhen you get to the front, she smiles at you, flashing sharp fangs. You force yourself not to step back and you [[place your order.|order]]

passages.name: believe in magic
passages.text: He ushers you out before you can ask for any explanation, and once in the waiting room you feel like you might need a hundred more.\n\nThe strange symbols have coalesced into something legible, something bright and shining, if still foreign, and the Receptionist’s book glows with an eerie light [[that you couldn’t see before|new sight]].

passages.name: yes magic
passages.text:
The world might say otherwise, but you can feel it in your gut. Magic has to be real.

The Hiring Manager's face twists into what might be a smile. “You have a lot of faith in what you can’t possibly know.” He sounds terribly patronizing, and you’re just about ready to leave this joke of an interview when he continues.

“But you’ll do. If you want it, the position is yours.”

[[Take the Job.|employ]]
[[Ask about Job.|askjob]]

passages.name: tat2
passages.text: She nods, and it begins. It doesn’t hurt, feels more like a group of very persistent kittens trying to scratch at you, but you have to focus. She might be drawing the sigil, but you’re weaving it with power.\n\nIn the end, it burns hotter than the golden amulet ever did, and you end up [[going to bed giddy|last day]], drunk with possibility. <<set $tattoo to true>>

passages.name: wh right 1
passages.text: You walk, and walk, and walk a little more. Everything looks the same.\n\n<<if visited() lte 2>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh right 1]]<<else>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh right 2]]<<endif>>

passages.name: wh right 3
passages.text: No song can make this walk any shorter. How much longer is it?\n\n<<if visited() lte 2>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh right 3]]<<else>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh mongoose]]<<endif>>

passages.name: wh right 2
passages.text: You start to hum a little song. It echoes terribly as you continue to walk forward.\n\n<<if visited() lte 2>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh right 2]]<<else>>[[Keep walking forward.|wh right 3]]<<endif>>

passages.name: Start
passages.text:
Arcane Intern (Unpaid)

A Twine game by Astrid Dalmady

[[Apply?|apply]]
[[Not your first application? Click here to jump between chapters.|jumper]] [[Credits]]

links.text: Not your first application? Click here to jump between chapters.

passages.name: t okay
passages.text:
You rush to check if she’s okay, finding her sitting down at the kitchen table. She looks, confused, looking around the room. Her eyes catch on the sigil you carved into the fridge for the first time and widen. 

Then she looks up at you and forgets. But she KNOWS she forgot.

“What’s going on?” Her voice is broken and confused. The kettle whistles, and is completely ignored.

[[Tell her the truth.|truth]]
[[Try to undo your spell.|undo]]

passages.name: expresso
passages.text:
She laughs, but it’s a nice laugh. Like she’s letting you in on a joke instead of making you the butt of one.

“Don’t worry, you’ll get the hang of things. I meant what I said. You’ll see what I mean once you get to the Otherworld. It’s in the basement, so don’t try going to Starbucks or anything.”

[[Ask about the different floors.|recept floors]]
[[Ask her what she’s smiling about.|recept smile]]
[[Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.|recept manage]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her what she’s smiling about.
Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.

passages.name: magazines
passages.text:
The magazines are 20 years out of date. Nothing like an in-depth interview about that boy band 5ive to kill the time.

“They’ll always be a thing” the magazine claims.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: apply
passages.text:
This is your seventh interview this week. The first two were for editorial positions, the next two book marketing. Internships #5 and #6 were Design and Publicity.

The ad for this one read ‘Arcane Intern Needed’, whatever that’s supposed to mean. 

Like all the others, it’s unpaid.

But you’re the one who wanted to get into book publishing, and that means internships. At the very least, this company has [[a nice waiting room.|waiting room]]<<set $minutes to 10>>

passages.name: t sigil
passages.text:
With a halting explanation, you tell her how the sigil gives you access. How anyone without one just forgets, the way she had once forgotten. You explain how you have to carry it everywhere.

Her eyes light up with bright, glorious insight. “Why not tattoo it on?” she says, before the spell buckles and she falls back into confusion.

[[Ask her for the tattoo.|tattoo]]
[[Suggest you both get tattoos.|both]]
[[Don’t risk any more experiments. Just undo your spell.|undo]]

links.text: Don’t risk any more experiments. Just undo your spell.

passages.name: cubicle
passages.text:
[[Several offices|hallway][$desk +=1]] extend past your cubicle and out into a winding hallway.

On your desk, the [[towers of paper|papers][$desk +=1]] lean on the [[ancient computer screen|computer][$desk +=1]]. Does it even work?

<<if $desk gte 4>>A door in the hallway opens, and a silvery voice [[beckons]].<<endif>>

passages.name: river of ink
passages.text:
This must be where Olivia Singh gets all that ink she uses. A river of it flows through the warehouse, bright crimson in a way blood never could be. You leap across the stream using footholds made of stained concrete and the remnants of crates.

You try not to get any on you. Stuff like that only ever marks mistakes.

<<if $find AND (visited("pens") is false)>>[[A shimmer of something you need.|pens]]<<endif>>
[[Towards the cauldron cairn.|wh left]]
[[Towards the feeling that someone is watching.|palintir]]
[[Towards the smell of disrepair.|rusted sigils]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

links.text: A shimmer of something you need.
Towards the feeling that someone is watching.

passages.name: Praecantatio Publishers
passages.text:
It was the name that drew you to the company despite the less than descriptive job posting. It shares a name with the magical school in the [[Rebecca Butler][$minutes -=1]] series.

Any company that’s a fan of those is somewhere you’re interested in working in.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: etch taylor
passages.text:
She frowns, and looks down at the sigil again.

“I don’t know… It's a bit abstract.”

But you cajole her, explain that it would make you less nervous. You lie, because you can’t stand lying to her over and over again, night after night.

In the end, she caves. You knew she would, and magic snaps and crackles as she draws on the both of you.

She stares at her own sigil, glowing with boundless energy and remembers. In the dead of night, her smile seems bright with possibility

“Thank you,” she says, and you spend the next few hours showing her what you know. Her lines are crisp and clear in the air and, when you finally [[fall asleep|last day]], you dream of magic. <<set $tattoo to true>><<set $taylor to true>>

passages.name: try magic
passages.text:
You can’t just read this and not do anything. You feel excitement buzzing in your blood, almost in time with the metallic hum of the art being made outside.

Picking up a pen, you walk up to your door and draw a sigil, curves bouncing in and out over the door frame. As the final line sinks in, the buzzing of the tattoo needle stops, just as you predicted, as magic cloaks the sound from entering the room.

You spend the rest of the night performing simple charms, and don’t bother to contain your glee. It’s not like Taylor can hear you anymore.

In the end, it’s only exhaustion that finally drives you [[to bed.|ch4]]

passages.name: copy sigil
passages.text:
The sigil does not struggle. Not as you copy it, nor as you tuck it into your pocket. 

The world seems brighter for a moment, before it fades back into the reality you’ve come to know. <<set $sigil to true>>

[[Back to work.|cr 2]]

passages.name: sr door
passages.text:
You knock, and a honeyed voice calls out from inside. 

“Don’t come in here!” Hisses. Scrapes. “You’ll only make them bigger!” Cheers. A sword being drawn.

“Why did it have to be snakes?”

[[Back away from the door and just head to the warehouse.|wh portal]] 
[[Ask if he needs any help?|door help]]

links.text: Back away from the door and just head to the warehouse.
Ask if he needs any help?

passages.name: w no magic
passages.text:
She laughs at you, just as brutal and correcting as the red ink that litters her desk.

“You’re welcome to try. Pick yourself up something nice from the warehouse, but I doubt anyone not born into this could ever make a working sigil. You’re no exception.”

She says this with no pity, only the smug satisfaction of someone who considers themselves better.

[[Calm yourself and just ask her what she needs from the warehouse.|warehouse]]

links.text: Calm yourself and just ask her what she needs from the warehouse.

passages.name: etch
passages.text:
You have an idea, and it sounds ridiculous, but what if they couldn’t take the sigil from you.

You slide the design over to her, and her eyes light up in understanding. She’s thrilled, having wanted to use you as a canvas since you first met.

Within moments, she’s all set up, sterilized and ready.

“Where do you want it?”

[[Upper arm.|tat2]]
[[Chest.|tat2]]
[[Wrist.|tat2]]
[[Leg.|tat2]]
[[Suggest you get matching tattoos.|etch taylor]]

passages.name: copy no eaves
passages.text: He’s a spiteful, small-minded man and anything he has to say will probably only hurt you. You head back into the safety of [[the copy room|cr 2]], trying not to imagine what he might have said.

passages.name: you startle
passages.text: His eyes are like chasms, but literally this time. They are pits of crushing blackness so deep that even the light around his eyes struggles before being inevitably sucked in.\n\nHe smiles again, “Oh, and while you’re here, it’d be best to [[believe in magic]].”

passages.name: stars
passages.text:
A perforated box at the top of a pile burns with an inner light that tosses strange shadows onto the hallway. It flickers like starlight, and like stars, is out of your reach.

[[Towards the perfume of paper.|books]]
[[Towards the smell of disrepair.|rusted sigils]]
[[Towards the rustle of wings.|paper birds]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: eavesdrop
passages.text:
You lean in towards the door, hearing his low voice mutter.

“I still don’t know why Talib even hired an outsider as an intern, but we’ll fix it soon. My nephew’s looking for a job, and this would be a perfect place for him.”

A soft voice, one you don’t recognize, replies.

“It is better to keep it to ourselves. You never know how outsiders will react to magic.”

[[You can't listen anymore.|cr 2]]

passages.name: something
passages.text:
You have taken something more valuable than musty old paperbacks. The copy of the viewing sigil, the one that opened up the world of magic, is still folded up neatly in your pocket.

With the amulet, it is temporary. Taking it off could leave you vacant and unknowing. But now you had the sigil.

[[Try to cast it.|cast]]
[[Try to etch it on to you.|etch]]

links.text: Try to etch it on to you.

passages.name: memo
passages.text: There’s a stack of books outside my office. Take them and copy the following pages in the following quantities to send by mail. MUST BE DONE BY TODAY. -Olivia Singh, Head Editor She signs it like that every time, never mind that you’ve been working here for almost 3 months now. You carry the books all the way to [[the copy room|copy room]] and get started. This is going to take all day, you can feel it.

passages.name: your bag
passages.text:
That’s weird. There’s a text from [[your roommate][$minutes -=1]] and a voicemail from [[your dad][$minutes -=1]]. But your phone hasn’t rung at all since you got here.

Maybe they were muffled under the weight of [[Rebecca Butler and the Sphinx’s Ink|Rebecca Butler][$minutes -=1]]. It’s the 13th in the series and sized to match.

[[Back|waiting room]]

links.text: Rebecca Butler and the Sphinx’s Ink

passages.name: delivery
passages.text:
Olivia Singh, unflappable editor, looks a little surprised at how fast you return with the supplies. Still, she seems to appreciate your talent.

“Good job. Maybe HR was right about you.” She takes a new pen and smirks. “Take this. See if you can do anything with it.”

She hands you a dusty paperback, the pages curled and yellowed. “This is for after work, you understand.”

You nod, gripping it tightly, eager to get back to your data entry, and more importantly to [[get back home to the book.|back home]]

links.text: get back home to the book.

passages.name: Taylor
passages.text:
You can’t take it anymore. You let it all out. The frustration, the crushing soullessness of how they treat you. You like the work, whenever they actually let you do things with the books, but the rest makes you feel so disposable.

You even tell her about the magic, about how thrilling it is to even do the simplest tasks because it’s all tangled up in this brand new world. Your golden sigil burns as you spill all your dirty secrets.

Once you finish your rant, she nods, her mind already forgetting the details of magic, but remembering all the rest.

“What assholes. Well if they’re using you, you should just use them back? Isn’t there something you can get out of this? Connections? Free books? Something?”

[[Nothing.|nothing]]
<<if $sigil>>[[…There is something.|something]]<<endif>>

passages.name: grunt
passages.text:
Olivia Singh — Head Editor — isn’t one of the worst offenders. She’s often too wrapped up in her corrections, forcing typos inside of magical manuscripts to change despite their desire to remain as they are. Her red pen blazes, even as she calls you into her office. 

You wait as she tackles a particularly troublesome comma splice. Eventually, she addresses you.

“Have you been to the warehouse yet?” Even as she speaks to you, she seems distracted, focused on something else.

[[You haven’t, but you ask her what she needs.|warehouse]]
[[You haven’t, but maybe you could do something here instead. Maybe finally learn some magic?|w no magic]]

links.text: You haven’t, but you ask her what she needs.
You haven’t, but maybe you could do something here instead. Maybe finally learn some magic?

passages.name: c copy 2
passages.text:
<<print either("A flight sigil flickers away from the copier. You spend half an hour trying to catch it.", "Flooding sigils should not be allowed in rooms full of paper. The fight to make that copy leaves you damp, and soggy for hours." , "You refuse to copy a fire sigil. You won’t be held responsible if this place burns down.","Roses and iris bloom from the copy machine. Vines sprout and cause a paper jam." , "A cockroach scurries out from under the machine. You hope it was summoned by the sigil.")>>

[[Keep copying.|c copy 2]]
[[Stop making copies.|copy room]]

passages.name: c copy 3
passages.text: <still refuse to copy a fire sigil. You aren’t nearly paid enough for that." , "A hot wind fills the room. It leaves you smelling like fabric softener, only not the brand you use." , "The toneless sound of the copier going back and forth gets stuck in your head. It's catchier than any pop song.")>> [[Keep copying.|c copy 3]] [[Stop making copies.|cr 2]]

passages.name: Otherworld Stylesheet
examine 2
passages.text: Taking a short break, you page through So You Married a Mage, and there it is, the sigil you are most familiar with. The sigil that gave you magic. It’s much clearer on the page than on your tiny golden amulet, and with what you know now, you think you could do it. But it’s complicated, and the moment you look away you can already feel the details slipping from your grasp. [[Make a copy.|copy sigil]] [[Better not risk it and the copy machine.|no copy sigil]]

links.text: Better not risk it and the copy machine.

passages.name: All Stylesheet
alba coffee
passages.text: You knock, and knock, and knock again. No answer comes. She must not be in today.\n\n[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

passages.name: bed
passages.text:
You swallow it all. What good could it do to talk to her? She’s just as clueless as you once were, blind to real world around her.

You mutter something vague about work and shut yourself up in your room. Even after a long shower, you can’t get the smell of ink and toner out of your skin.

[[Go to sleep.|last day]]

passages.name: home taylor
passages.text:
That night, you and Taylor celebrate. You laugh and sip elf-made wine deep into the night, until your muscles and mind are loose from warmth and fatigue.

“You know,” Taylor says, iridescent with her new knowledge. “We really shouldn’t keep this all to ourselves.”

You have a feeling she isn’t referring to the wine, but you ask anyway.

“Well if all it takes is a tattoo, then we should just do it. Spread the word. I’ll show all the artists, take it to all the trade shows. We could blow this world wide open.”

[[Smile.|smile end]]
[[Frown.|smile end]]

passages.name: employ
passages.text:
His smile is an omen. Of what, you’re not sure, but it sends a shiver down your spine as he congratulates you.

“Now there will be some things to sign on Monday, but for today, you’ll get your entry key.”

He slides a length of chain across to you and grins. On the end, there is a strange symbol. “Go ahead,” he says. “[[Put it on.|put it on]]”

passages.name: cast
passages.text:
You ask if she can make some tea, a warm ritual you’ve shared before on days when the job hunt went bad or her clients wanted particularly bad tattoos. She jumps, eager to help and it leaves you alone at the table.

You pull out the page and focus. It’s complex, bending under your eye, but you can do this. You have learned how to bend the universe to your will and this will be no different.

The air takes on a static tinge, as you wave your hand. Up, around, downwards in a cutting motion, spreading your fingers wide. You juggle to keep all the pieces together, and you feel it tense, and tense and grow.

And snap like a rubber band.

Magic, pure and heavy and electric fills the apartment, cloying in its power. Taylor yelps from the kitchen.

[[See if she’s okay.|t okay]]
[[Call it a night. You’re exhausted.|exhausted]]

links.text: Call it a night. You’re exhausted.

passages.name: ch2
passages.text:
Intern To-Do List

    <>
  1. [[Get Coffee]]
  2. Restock Storage Room
  3. Making Copies

passages.name: ch3
passages.text:
Intern To-Do List

    <>
  1. Get Coffee
  2. [[Restock Storage Room|sr start]]
  3. Making Copies

passages.name: ch4
passages.text:
Intern To-Do List

    <>
  1. Get Coffee
  2. Restock Storage Room
  3. [[Making Copies|copies start]]

passages.name: own world
passages.text:
Like always, your breathing is easier here. Your body is lighter, but only because there is an emptiness. Still, there is a certain comfort in your home world, despite its enmeshment with the mundane.

<<if $skullname>>[[Look in on the Janitor.|j end]]<<endif>>
[[Deliver the supplies.|delivery]]

passages.name: palintir
passages.text:
A darkened orb sits on a pillar. You feel like you’re being watched. You pass by it, and your shadow warps uncomfortably.

[[Towards the growls.|chimera]] 
[[Towards the sound of a stream.|river of ink]] 
[[Towards the cauldron cairn.|wh left]] 
[[Backtrack.|previous()]] 
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

links.text: Towards the sound of a stream.

passages.name: skull list
passages.text:
You place the list in front of the flaming skull and ask for his help in finding these things among the piles and piles of stuff that litter the warehouse.

Eyeless sockets look down and it smiles.

“To the left you can harvest the pens, on the other side of the river of ink. Obviously. And the books you need are near the paper bird cages or the stars, just go right until you hit the heads. It’s easy from there.”

Then its face seems to contort. Impossible since bones can’t move the way muscles do, but it’s the impression it gives nonetheless.

“The post-it notes are tricky. You need to go faaaaaaar right from here, and I mean far, and take down that mongoose. It’s a pain. There are several spells you could use to catch it, but the easiest is just to get rid of it. Just inscribe this banishing sigil in the air and it’ll buzz off.”

Its flames curve to form a sweeping line, a series of circles, and the shuddering feeling of not being wanted. The sigil is burned in your mind now.

“You got all that?”<<set $find to true>>

[[Yeah, got it.|skull list 2]]
[[Uh, could you give me a map or something?|skull map]]

links.text: Uh, could you give me a map or something?

passages.name: your roommate
passages.text:
‘Bringing home BBQ for dinner. Pick up some napkins, will you?’

You smile. You won the fucking lottery when you got Taylor for a roommate. You were skeptical at first. She’s got tons of tattoos and terrible taste in music, but you guys click really well.

It helps that her tattoo artist gig actually pays, and she doesn’t hold the disparity against you.

[[Back to your bag.|your bag]]
[[Back to the waiting room.|waiting room]]

passages.name: Descend
passages.text: Walking through the vortex feels like walking through an automatic car wash. Something that feels wet but isn’t splashes against your face, only to be swept away by a fearsome wind.\n\nYou end up [[on the other side]], feeling pretty clean, even though your hair is a mess.

passages.name: breakroom
passages.text:
You keep a snack in your desk now, and take advantage of the silence in your cubicle. You wonder if you’ll ever get an office here, instead of a desk hastily assembled in the hallway.

You wonder if you even want one.

On the way back to the copy room, you pass by the closed door of the break room. You hear Nigel Scott’s self-important drone, and you’re ready to ignore it, until he says your name.

[[Eavesdrop.|eavesdrop]]
[[Ignore him.|copy no eaves]]

passages.name: nigel coffee
passages.text:
“Forgotten already? Figures. A Draconian Latte, and make sure you get it right.”

The door slams behind you, even though you tried to close it gently.

[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

passages.name: no magic
passages.text:
You’ve learned the hard way. Magic isn’t real.

The Hiring Manager smiles. “Of course not.” He sounds terribly patronizing, and you’re just about ready to leave this joke of an interview when he continues.

“You’re perfect. If you want it, the position is yours.”

[[Take the Job.|employ]]
[[Ask about Job.|askjob]]

passages.name: exhausted
passages.text: You call out that you’ve changed your mind about the tea, and trudge into your room.\n\nYou [[fall asleep|last day]] as soon as your head hits the pillow, still clinging with static energy.

passages.name: wh left
passages.text:
Just a few steps in and you already feel like you’re in a labyrinth. A stack of cauldrons acts as a cairn, marking the first crossroads in this twisted warehouse.

<<if $map>>[[Go straight to the pens.|pens]]
[[Go straight to the books.|books]]<<endif>>
[[Towards the feeling that someone is watching.|palintir]]
[[Towards the sound of a stream.|river of ink]]
[[Towards the smell of disrepair.|rusted sigils]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

links.text: Towards the feeling that someone is watching.
Towards the sound of a stream.

passages.name: talib coffee
passages.text:
You knock and a familiar female voice tells you to come in. You do, and find yourself in the waiting room from your interview.

But how? the interview had happened on the first floor, and the offices were on the third floor. You didn’t go down any stairs or anything.

The receptionist — a Ms. Tran, her name plaque reads now — is at the desk, grinning smugly.

[[Ask about the different floors.|recept floors]]
[[Ask her what she’s smiling about.|recept smile]]
[[Ask her for her coffee order.|recept coffee]]
[[Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.|recept manage]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her what she’s smiling about.
Ask her for her coffee order.
Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.

passages.name: skull warehouse
passages.text:
The skull tilts towards you, as if catching sight of your golden sigil.

“Ah, that does explain things. This is just an Otherworld warehouse, a kind of space out of space. Not exactly safe for you humans to be in, like most of the Otherworld, but you should be fine.”

It grins, but then again, it’s always grinning.

“Personally though, I wouldn’t be flashing that thing around, even if it does help you get here. Some people think you aren’t really magical unless you got the symbol etched at birth, but that’s a load of crock. Still, they’ll think less of you.”

<<if $skullname AND visited("skull help") is 0>>[[Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.|skull help]]<<endif>>
[[Ask where to find the things on your list.|skull list]]
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]

links.text: Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.
Ask where to find the things on your list.

passages.name: chimera
passages.text:
Something growls within closed boxes. A flash of a scaled tail, the glint of claws, a rustle of fur. Whatever it is, its shadow even looks menacing, and you make an effort to stay away.

[[Towards the feeling that someone is watching.|palintir]]
[[Towards what feels like a trap.|nets]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

links.text: Towards the feeling that someone is watching.
Towards what feels like a trap.

passages.name: receptionist
passages.text:
The Receptionist is engrossed in a giant leather bound book. Bothering her seems rude when she’s studying such a difficult book.

It has to be, since the letters wobble strangely whenever you try to look at them. So you don't.

[[Back|waiting room]]

passages.name: j end
passages.text:
The room is silent, but when you knock, the voice crops up, smooth even in its exhaustion.

“Oh. You’re back. Good. Just taking a break over here. The snakes are entrenching now, so there’s not much I can do.”

[[Wish them luck and move on.|wish]]
<<if $mongoose>>[[Offer up the mongoose.|j mongoose]]<<endif>>

links.text: Wish them luck and move on.

passages.name: tell magic
passages.text:
You tell her what happened. Of the chasm eyes and gargoyles and glowing sigils in the street.

She nods and the eye sigil is hot against your skin. You wait to see her reaction.

“Will they at least pay for your lunch?”

She didn’t seem to hear it. Just like you didn’t see the Hiring Manager’s eyes. Just like the symbols meant nothing to you until now.

You say yes. [[At least there’s that.|ch2]]

passages.name: wh right
passages.text:
You step down into the corridor. Despite being awfully messy, there is nothing of interest in the walls. Only plain, poorly stacked boxes and a long way forward.

<<if visited("wh mongoose") OR $map>>[[Just rush to the mongoose.|wh mongoose]]<<endif>>
[[Walk forward|wh right 1]]

passages.name: wh center
passages.text:
Tall stacks of boxes, all of varying sizes and styles, are piled on top of each other as far as the eye can see. Treasure chests perched atop cardboard boxes balanced atop empty birdcages. 

[[To your left|wh left]], thin hallways snake deeper into the warehouse, splitting quickly before dashing into the shadows.

[[In front of you|wh help]], a shuttered booth built into the wall of stuff has a sign that reads ‘Ring Bell for Assistance’.

[[To your right|wh right]], a wide sweeping corridor cuts through the debris, like someone has run a snowplow to make this road. It goes forward so far, the path seems to dissolve into a haze of darkness and dust motes.

/%code for exit path check%/

passages.name: capture
passages.text:
A scrap of paper floats its way towards you from above. You catch it, sigil burning on the page and in your mind. But the flames that like the paper don't turn it, nor your hand to ash. It keeps it trapped, tamed.

That's what this sigil does.<<set $capture to true>>

[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: end credits
passages.text:
Thank you for playing Arcane Intern (Unpaid)

Let me know what you thought on twitter or tumblr, and sign up to the Dastridly Deeds email list for updates on any new projects.
You can also check out my website for more games, podcasts and stories. You've reached the following endings: <>1. Oblivious<>1. ????<> <>2. WiziLeaks<>2. ????<> <>3. Yer a Wizard<>3. ????<>
Hint: Choices that determine an ending are only found in your final to-do item, but you may have missed some information in the others. So try again. Explore. Help others. Deny Them. Make the Most of Magic.
Back to the Main Menu [[Credits]]

passages.name: What?
passages.text:
“I’m sorry, let me speak a little clearer. What is your favorite color?”

Okay. So maybe this is some Google interview bullshit.

[[Red|Colors]]
[[Blue|Colors]]
[[Green|Colors]]
[[Purple|Colors]]
[[Yellow|Colors]]
[[Black|Colors]]

passages.name: pay
passages.text:
She grins, fangs flashing in the dim cafe light. “The company handled it, but if you’d like to pay more…”

You shake your head vehemently and step aside to wait for your order.

A few minutes later, the dragon rumbles a name you vaguely recognize as yours and you pickup the tray of colorfully steaming beverages.

They’ll get cold if you loiter, so you head back out, away from the ‘Caffeine Hoard’ and all its denizens.

Despite the experience, you can’t help but feel lonely [[once you return|return]].

passages.name: otherworld nigel
passages.text:
You’ve seen people look at gum stuck to the bottom of their shoe with more regard than the way Nigel is looking at you now.

“The Otherworld. Magical Dimension that exists in tandem to our own. Home of all magical creatures—” He stops and makes an exasperated noise.

“Why am I bothering explaining this to you? Just go to the basement and get us all our coffee, and quickly.”

[[Leave the office.|coffee start]]

passages.name: back home
passages.text:
Taylor, like you, sometimes brings her work home with her. Tonight she’s sitting out in the dining room, sketchbooks spread open in front of her as she tries out a new technique on her favorite canvas: herself.

You don’t disrupt her, as you head straight for your room and shut the door. The dull buzz of the needle acts as background noise as you crack open the tome and grin at the simple charms held within.

[[Try one out.|try magic]]
[[Keep it theoretical.|theory]]

passages.name: Credits
passages.text: Writing and Development by Astrid Dalmady Backgrounds from Transparent Textures and Subtle Patterns Scripts from Glorious Trainwrecks Magic Circle from Wikimedia Commons And a huge thank you to Gabi, Alex, Sierra, Erica, Cynthia, Sam, Melanie and Emily for play testing! [[Back|previous()]]

passages.name: skull help
passages.text:
“Magical snakes?! Urgh, nasty creatures. Well the best thing for magical snakes is a magical mongoose. You could try to catch the one here, I guess.” 

It looks around and sighs.

“Can’t remember the spell for that though. Should be out by the nets though. That’s a left at the sigil graveyard.”

[[Ask where to find the things on your list.|skull list]]
[[Ask about the warehouse.|skull warehouse]]
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]

links.text: Ask where to find the things on your list.

passages.name: coffee start
passages.text:
The hallway extends far down to the right, farther than the building would seem to allow from the outside. At least all of the doors are labeled, each with their own bronze plaque and arcane symbols.

[[Alba DuBois - CEO|alba coffee]]
[[Olivia Singh - Head Editor|olivia coffee]]
[[Nigel Scott - Marketing Director|nigel coffee]]
[[Talib Hoth - Human and Non-Human Resources|talib coffee]]
[[🜆 🜣 🝑 🝉 - Janitor|janitor coffee]]
[[Basement|basement]]

links.text: Talib Hoth - Human and Non-Human Resources

passages.name: forest
passages.text:
The boxes grow up and up, like massive tree trunks. You weave between the stacks, trying to make your way through what resembles a forest path.

Really the only difference between this and a real forest is that this wood is quiet, artificial and dead.

[[Forge ahead.|bell]]
[[Backtrack.|previous()]]
[[Back to the entrance.|wh end test]]

passages.name: doors
passages.text: Alba DuBois - CEO Olivia Singh - Head Editor Nigel Scott - Marketing Director Talib Hoth - Human and Non-Human Resources 🜆 🜣 🝑 🝉 - Janitor The last two are the only doors with lights. You wonder why Talib’s name was the one that slipped your mind when you don’t even know how to start saying the Janitor’s name. [[Back to your desk.|cubicle]]

passages.name: papers
passages.text: Even magical companies have finances, and their papers are just as esoteric. Still, some of the titles are interesting. So You’ve Married a Mage Simple Hexes for Home Safety 50 Stupid Easy Spell Sigils Lots of alliteration, if nothing else. [[Back to your desk.|cubicle]]

passages.name: interview
passages.text:
“Punctual. That’s a good sign.”

The Hiring Manager has a voice like a chasm, and eyes like them too.  He sits behind a desk with no computer, and stands to shake your hand.

Names are traded. Yours must not have been worth the trade, because his name slips your mind immediately.

“Let’s not waste any time, and begin with the important questions.” He steeples his fingers and frowns, considering the grave matter before you. You begin to sweat.

“What is your favorite color?”

[[“What?”|What?]]
[[Red|Colors]]
[[Blue|Colors]]
[[Green|Colors]]
[[Purple|Colors]]
[[Yellow|Colors]]
[[Black|Colors]]

passages.name: wh help
passages.text:
<<if $bell is true>>\s
A flaming skull floats inside the once closed help booth. Despite not having any facial expressions, it still manages to look bored.

[[Ask where to find the things on your list.|skull list]]
[[All about the warehouse.|skull warehouse]]
<<if $skullname is true>>[[Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.|skull help]]<<endif>>
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]
<<else>>
The booth is obviously closed, covered up by thick planks of wood. You look around for the bell you need to ring for assistance, but find nothing.

<<if $skullname>>[[Call for help.|skull name]]<<endif>>
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]<<endif>>

links.text: Ask where to find the things on your list.
Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.

passages.name: new sight
passages.text:
There is so much you couldn’t see before. The slate grey tiles of the building outside now match the gargoyles perched upon the windows. Every so often, a house is marked with one of those symbols and where before you would forget them, now they blaze in your memory.

You stumble back to your shitty apartment, seeing less and less sigils as you go. Your roommate Taylor is already there.

[[Tell her about magic.|tell magic]]
[[Don’t tell her. It’s nuts.|dont tell]]

passages.name: askjob
passages.text:
The listing didn’t say much about what you’d be doing, and the Hiring Manager manages to almost say even less.

“Oh, you know. Getting Coffee, Restocking the Storage Room, Making copies. Normal intern things.”

[[Take the Job.|employ]]
[[That doesn’t sound great.|references]]

passages.name: hallway
passages.text: All the offices have their doors tightly shut, but even then you can see sparks of light flicker through the cracks below [[a few of the doors|doors][$desk +=1]].\n\n[[Back to your desk.|cubicle]]

passages.name: c examine
passages.text: Here’s one of the books you read about earlier in those financial reports. So You’ve Married a Mage. The copy that’s toppled from the stack has had its cover ripped off. You’re busy now, but you’ll take a closer look later. [[Back|copy room]]

passages.name: tattoo
passages.text:
You wait, until the confusion has passed and you slide the copied page with the sigil to her and ask for the favor.

She doesn’t hesitate. She’s been eager to use you as a canvas ever since you moved in. Within moments, she’s all set up, sterilized and ready.

“Where do you want it?”

[[Upper arm.|tat2]]
[[Chest.|tat2]]
[[Wrist.|tat2]]
[[Leg.|tat2]]

passages.name: Secrets
passages.text: “Honest answer, I admire that. Just one more question.”\n\n[[“Do you believe in magic?”|magic]]

passages.name: front page css
passages.text: body {\nbackground: url("arcaneimages/paper.png"), url("arcaneimages/magic-circle.png") no-repeat 90% 150%;\n}

passages.name: j mongoose
passages.text:
There is a pause, and the door creaks open. You see a glimpse of something bone white, then darkness.

“I can’t thank you enough! A magical mongoose is the best thing for magical snakes. Just let it slip in here.” You release your furry necktie into the darkness, where it leaps gleefully, almost whooping as it bounds in.

The door clicks shut, but you can almost feel the Janitor smiling behind it. “Don’t let any of the others tell you anything, you’re the best intern we’ve ever had, and a fine mage if this capture sigil is any sign. Keep it up, and don’t let them bully you away.”

It shouldn’t affect you much, but it does, the praising filling you with a warm glow. So much else has gone out of its way to make you feel unwelcome, but at least someone here can see that you belong.

[[Go finish your deliveries.|delivery]]

passages.name: last day
passages.text:
Nothing ever changes at work though. Endless numbers, endless slights from the staff. In the end, you aren’t really surprised when HR calls you into the office, the receptionist looking at you with pity.

“It’s a shame,” Mr. Hoth says, eyes shining like pits. “But I’m afraid you’re not quite the fit we were looking for here.”

You swallow heavily, as the euphemism for ‘You’re Fired’ hits just as hard as if it’d just been said outright.

But that isn’t the worst of it all.

“We’re going to need your viewing sigil.” 

He says, and holds his hand out to you.

[[Don't give it back.|last keep]]
[[Give it back.|last give]]

passages.name: StoryAuthor
passages.text: Astrid Dalmady

passages.name: nothing
passages.text: No. There’s nothing. Not anything more than the pilfered books and furtive studying you’ve already done. \n\nTaylor grins sympathetically anyway. She pats your hand and says all the right things and [[you go to bed|last day]] still feeling frustrated and useless.

passages.name: c copy
passages.text:
Making copies is arduous work, even with the machine. Magical sigils don’t want to be copied. They want to sink into the paper, into whatever they’re written on and not budge. So each copy takes several tries.

The light slides back and forth, trying to force a sigil to be tame.

[[Keep copying.|c copy 2]]
[[Back|copy room]]

passages.name: last keep
passages.text: You try to keep it, clutching to the warm golden comfort but there is a weight to his words. It’s as if they were spoken in whatever tongue the sigils comes from, instead of English. \n\n<<if $tattoo>>In the end, no matter what you might want, [[you drop it in his hand.|knowing]]<<else>>In the end, no matter what you might want, [[you drop it in his hand.|forget]]<<endif>>

links.text: you drop it in his hand.
you drop it in his hand.

passages.name: recept smile
passages.text:
“Oh, just you. It’s always amusing to watch newbies deal with the arcane. But I’m sure you’ll get the hang of it. Mr. Hoth wouldn’t have hired you otherwise.”

[[Ask about the different floors.|recept floors]]
[[Ask her for her coffee order.|recept coffee]]
[[Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.|recept manage]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her for her coffee order.
Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.

passages.name: skull name
passages.text:
It feels pretty awkward, but you call the name the Janitor gave you. It feels like an oil slick on your mouth, but the effects are instantaneous.

The wood in front of the booth bursts into wreathing purple flames, rising, and rising. You panic for a moment, thinking the flames might spread, but they vanish, turning to sparks in the air.

Where they began, a floating, flaming skull grins out from the darkness of the booth.

“You rang?”

<<if $skullname AND (visited("skull help") is false)>>[[Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.|skull help]]<<endif>>
[[Ask where to find the things on your list.|skull list]]
[[Ask about the warehouse.|skull warehouse]]
[[Back to the warehouse.|wh center]]

links.text: Ask what you can do to help the Janitor.
Ask where to find the things on your list.

passages.name: copies start
passages.text: With a yellowed paperback, and smuggled notes, you begin to fuel your magical education. You soundproof your room, rot proof the fridge. Sigils litter the apartment and even Taylor notices that something is different, even if the spell keeps her from knowing what. You feel like a character in a book, like Rebecca Butler studying magic under cover of night in Rebecca Butler and the Pillars of Storge. But every hero needs a villain, and every spell has a price. Today, the boredom of work is your punishment. While occasionally you’ll get a meaningful task, it’s still mostly struggling with Windows 95 and forcing sales numbers into the Excel spreadsheet. You welcome the reprieve when a memo, [[one of those paper birds|memo]], flutters onto your desk.

passages.name: recept floors
passages.text:
“Oh, just some old construction work. Transport sigils on the door frames. It only works half the time now, but little Ms. CEO can’t spare the magic to fix it.” 

Her fingers curl on the edge of her book. You wisely don’t press the issue.

[[Ask her for her coffee order.|recept coffee]]
[[Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.|recept manage]]
[[Back to the hallway.|coffee start]]

links.text: Ask her for her coffee order.
Ask her where the Hiring Manager is.

passages.name: dragon
passages.text: The dragon looks exactly like how you imagined it to look like when you first read Rebecca Butler and the Scales of Destiny . Smoke rises from its nostrils, obscuring its glinting cat-like eyes. You notice it sorting the beans with razor sharp claws and dropping them into a grinder. They have the same kind that you used during your short stint as a Starbucks employee. [[Back to the cafe.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: home door
passages.text:
The apartment is silent as you arrive. You lock yourself in your room, and just read. They tried to take this from you, so you will learn it all.

Magic will submit to you, spilling its secrets page by page.

You think back on being eleven and cracking open the very first Rebecca Butler book. Truth, you realize, tastes a thousand times better than fiction.<<remember $soloend to true>>

[[The End|end credits]]

passages.name: hag excuse
passages.text: You avert your gaze and she cackles. It doesn’t sound like any laugh you’ve ever heard before, even in the movies.\n\n[[Back to the cafe.|cafe hoard]]

passages.name: order
passages.text:
“Oh, you must be the new intern at the Praecantatio. It was about time they got a fresh one.” 

You just nod as she puts in your order, and nods you aside.

[[Should you pay now?|pay]]
[[Well if she’s not gonna mention it…|not pay]]

links.text: Well if she’s not gonna mention it…
